issues.description: The template file template_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Farm.java does not declare the expected Farm class described in the problem statement UML; instead it declares a public class named AnimalFarm and even contains an illegal nested 'package' declaration and duplicated class code inside a method. This is a structural mismatch with the exercise specification (which expects a class named Farm with the listed attributes and methods) and with the solution (which provides a proper Farm class). The template as-is will cause compilation errors (public class name not matching file name, nested package declaration inside method) and prevents students from starting from a correct stub for the Farm class, blocking them from implementing the intended design.
issues.suggested_fix: Replace the broken template file content with a syntactically correct stub for the Farm class that matches the problem UML. At minimum, the file template_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Farm.java should declare 'package de.tum.cit.ase;' and 'public class Farm { ... }' (not AnimalFarm), include a private List<Animal> animals field, a no-argument constructor that initializes the ArrayList, and method stubs with correct signatures: getAnimals(), setAnimals(List<Animal>), addAnimal(Animal), feedAllAnimals(), singFarmSong(), and a private singFarmSongVerse(Animal). Remove the duplicated package declaration and nested class content currently embedded inside a method so the template compiles and students can implement the intended design.

issues.description: The problem statement (and the solution) expect a class named 'Farm' (with methods like addAnimal, feedAllAnimals, singFarmSong and an 'animals' attribute). The template repository instead declares a class named 'AnimalFarm' inside template_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Farm.java. This naming mismatch (and the filename/class-name mismatch) prevents students from mapping the described/required 'Farm' entity to the provided template code, will likely cause compilation/test failures, and creates unnecessary cognitive overhead as students search for a 'Farm' class that is not present under the expected name.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the class in the template from 'AnimalFarm' to 'Farm' (and ensure the public class name matches the file name Farm.java). Also restore/align the expected method and attribute signatures (addAnimal, feedAllAnimals, singFarmSong, and the 'animals' List) so the template directly corresponds to the problem description and the solution reference.
